Gloomhaven is a relatively engaging and gamey implementation of a dungeon crawl that treads new ground rather than relying on familiar mechanics like 20 sided dice. The story creates a side veneer of interest that propels character advancement and investment in the proceedings but the whole thing would be overwrought and uninteresting without the core card play mechanic.

Said card system is both the strength and weakness of this game as a whole. It creates a puzzly situation each turn where you have to think through optimum play for both now and the future while also trying to take into account what the monsters are going to do (semi-random) and what your team is going to do (contextual on good communication and teamwork). The system does make for more interesting decisions than most dungeon crawlers, but the reliance that the system creates on effective teamwork is both good and bad in that it requires a fully invested, pretty cooperative team all on the ball to really hum as it is challenging enough to require that level of engagement, even with lower level monsters the inherent nature of the card play requires several steps of look ahead and makes this a fairly challenging game to play competently.

This smaller box is a much, much better introduction than the original game as it actually has a series of starter scenarios that teach you how to play rather than just throwing you into the deep end with a ton of cards and abilities to understand like the base game. If you are interested in Gloomhaven and want to try it out then this is definitely the place to start. That said, there is a tipping point beyond the first few scenarios where your character decks open up again and that is close to the same degree of overwhelming as it is out of the gates in the main game; what hope I had to enjoy it more than the main box quickly went by the wayside once it opened up.

The Legacy component in this does suffer a bit in that it doesn't have quite the same grandiosity, as the scenario book is a map, and while it makes setup easier, it does limit the game a bit, but if you like it enough to play it into the ground the 25 scenarios should keep you busy for quite a while.

As with base: you want spin down monster token holders (for HP tracking). It speeds play a lot. Even with those, this thing is fiddly to set up and play in terms of the physical stuff you're dealing with and keeping track of.

Final assessment: I like the idea of this, but the implementation leaves me dissatisfied. All of the issues of slow combat in D&D are exacerbated here by the straight jacket that the card system puts on everything that you do in game. I find it odd that the most challenging thing in this game often ends up being just having the ability to move enough to effectively take your combat actions.

While this gamey puzzle element is undoubtedly what the fans love about it, I find it obnoxious in practice; as so much of it is reliant on the team working together and a single action taken by one player can have negative cascading effects on the other players because of how actions are selected at the start of the round. Hence, optimal play would be the living hell of alpha player dictating actions to the team. Not having some table talk would make this impossible to be successful in though, so it ends up trying to split the baby with the suggestions in the rules (which effective amount to: table talk, but in general terms only) that try to obscure this core issue. I think I would have ultimately enjoyed this game a lot more if initiative was a separate roll or mechanic from the actions and players were allowed to just choose their actions when their turn comes up. Having movement not being tied to the cards would also likely have improved my enjoyment of it as well. The existing system is moderately more elegant, but it makes the play pretty dissatisfying to me and some of the players we may have otherwise enjoyed this game with.

At the end of the day, this takes the thing I dislike most about post 3.0 D&D (endless array of special powers you have to keep track of and combo with each other like a video game) and ports it into a puzzley board game that makes that the whole shebang. It's not a bad design per se, but it's not for me and I don't care to play it again. My ratings ultimately reflect how much I want or would be willing to play it, not its "objective" quality, hence the 2.

Jaws of the Lion is a very confused game. It wants to be an RPG game with character development and player agency, but it's actually a board game with limited choice, terrible characters that don't develop beyond getting skill cards and no agency in your actions. It wants to be a computer game, but it's still a board game with all the limitations therein (players have to handle all NPC decision making and movement, small maps that are tactically limited, lots of tokens/pieces for each type of enemy).

If you're going to put that much effort into a table top game, play D&D or Pathfinder. You'll have a better time with less effort and more options.
OR if you hate the hassle of learning all the rules and handling all the tokens: play a computer game like Into The Breach or XCOM. You'll have more enemies, bigger/better maps, more variability, while your odds won't be tied to simplistic mechanics like how many cards are in your attack deck.

There are better games to play.

The problem with Gloomhaven is that it's not a game. It's a story you play along with, like an elaborate "choose your own adventure". This doesn't mean it can't be fun. I believe it can be very fun, with the right people who want to do the adventure with you. I have done so, and can completely confirm that this is true. However, there's literally nothing fun about this solo. If it's done solo, then you must rely on the storytelling of the "game" itself. And that story is weak. The story can only truly be developed with other people. This brings it to another reason why it's not a game, but rather a "cooperative adventure book sort of thing". There is no true victory condition other than merely going through the book front to back. I'm sure I'm not the first to say or the last. This would be great if you have a son or daughter to spend a Saturday morning every week for 30 weekends doing this activity. But then when you're done, what have you built together other than time well-spent? That is great with loved-ones, but not something I would prefer with strangers. This is a 25-40 session event, with wasch session lasting 2-4 hours. This can, in theory, be done in a few weeks, but you won't get much else in life done, other than your job, eating and sleeping. The story that is created by this cooperative adventure then becomes critical to the enjoyment. And the story as written is just, well, worse than nearly all fantasy books I've read. The artists were not storytellers. They wanted to create the story in the adventurers.

Jaws of the Lion has gotten a lot of love lately. I've played Gloomhaven about 10 times or so now and it's a game I do really enjoy but rarely want to pull out. I simultaneously am impressed with Jaws of the Lion and expected more. Let's talk about it

One of the first and most jarring things that has changed is the rulebook. I thought the original rulebook was a bit of a slog. Jaws of the Lion's uses a tutorial campaign approach. I thought it worked okay, but I wasn't crazy about the rules presentation. Overall it feels like the rules stretch on for longer and are harder to read ahead of time. I prefer rule books to be structured more as reference manuals than tutorials most of the time (an example of play is always welcome though). The rules overhead in Jaws of the Lion is lower than in Gloomhaven by quite a lot, but it's still higher than you might expect

Spoon feeding also doesn't give you a good taste of the game. The first scenario gives you only six cards and the enemies don't use AI cards. I personally found this a bit too simplistic. The second scenario switches out some of your cards for slightly more complex cards and gives the AI a limited deck. This is a little bettter, but I felt this should've perhaps been game 1. Being limited to six fairly basic cards again still doesn't really whet your palate for what Gloomhaven actually feels like. Overall the progression here works and is more streamlined, but I think it's possibly a step too far (which I'd prefer over the contrary)

The terrain in the book is an economical choice and a good one. It doesn't streamline the game all that much, but I also didn't feel like the game was missing anything by using the book. Solid and smart choice. The integrated tips on the boards are particuarly nice

My biggest criticism (aside from the pacing) is that this set only has 4 characters. Gloomhaven has a ton of characters and overall a lot more content (arguably more than double what Jaws of the Lion has). While Jaws of the Lion is quicker to setup and likely my preferred way to play solo, vanilla Gloomhaven is - in my opinion - a better product and a better way to get introduced to the game (especially if you are being taught). Jaws of the Lion is very watered down to start - to the point where I think some people will walk away without ever having experienced the depth the game has to offer. Rather Jaws of the Lion is a good addition to a Gloomhaven collection as it gives you easy scenarios to introduce new players to - I just wouldn't recommend it over the base game. I will happily play through this, but I doubt I will pick it up. You could easily house rule a few scenarios in base Gloomhaven to spoon feed rules if you'd like

Interesting card system, good value for money I guess, but ultimately a bit of a mess of genres. It's a fusion of Euro and Dungeon Crawler yet falls short on both counts. On the surface it's a precise card-efficiency puzzle engine but before long you will find a heap of edge cases left hanging in the wind - "I'm a tight Euro, except when I'm not....". Two entirely conflicting styles of game design both of which I enjoy but not when they are shoe-horned together.

It's also a co-op experience and yet has restrictions to communication built into the system, probably to encourage the 'element of surprise' (to make up for the lack of dice...) or to avoid any alpha players taking over, but it doesn't work - you can't tell other players what number cards you plan to play but you can tell them what you plan to do...kind of?? It's a muddy rule that feels very unsatisfying to try and incorporate as players.

Rewards are also incredibly dull. Trekking half-way across the map for...drumroll...a coin feels like the dungeon is laughing in my face - "You thought you were going to find something exciting...think again." Where are the highs and lows that are a prerequisite to a dungeon crawl experience?

Oh, and the story is naff.

Most of these thoughts based on one 4p campaign, but revised a bit after getting more experience with full Gloomhaven.

Excellent stuff:
* Great experience to work through a campaign as a group, playing with the same people and getting to know the characters.
* The Gloomhaven system and gameplay deserves the hype. Strategy is fun and it gives rise to some really wild sessions where things go completely sideways and you squeak through anyway.
* Strategically not as interesting as some of my favorites. But I've come to appreciate that this system is more about improvising and leaning into good heuristics rather than being able to plan everything.
* Characters are very well-designed and all have unique skills. I played as the Red Guard but I'm interested in trying all the other ones. And even as the Red Guard I could've built up the deck quite differently.
* Getting better with your character, learning their strengths and figuring out how to manage your deck.
* Once in a while things line up and you get a magic turn where everything clicks, and goodness is that satisfying.

OK stuff:
* Overarching story is not really interesting at all. (Though I have enjoyed the hammy narration app.)

Not good stuff:
* Too often 4p scenarios had that feel I associate with frustrating video game levels where every setup feels like a painful slog you just want to get through as quickly as possible.
* Some later levels seen uninspired, just wave after wave of respawning elite monsters pummeling you into exhaustion. I honestly wonder if they play-tested 4p very thoroughly on some of these. Maybe they were limited by the binder format.
* Nearly all scenarios are way, way longer than the 30 minutes/player estimated on the box.
* I know they had to cut some costs here and there to get it on the shelf at Target, but buyers are likely going to want to spend more to improve the experience. I bought some monster standees with damage counters because tracking damage for lots of monsters is really tedious and error-prone. Meanwhile there's a map and stickers that don't add anything to the game.

Overall, well, I don't know. When we wrapped up the campaign, no one wanted to jump into full Gloomhaven. I eventually did, playing digitally, and honestly loved it. I'm usually for tabletop over digital, but there's so much overhead in this system sometimes to manage all the characters, initiatives, monsters, elements, etc., playing digitally really let me focus on core gameplay. So maybe this all reflects JOTL's limitations, or the system is too much on tabletop, or having four people just exponentially grew the playtime and overhead into something that didn't work.
